summary: A letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office to Judge Richard M. Berman regarding the case against Jeffrey Epstein, responding to Epstein's claim about his expired Austrian passport and noting the passport shows evidence of use in the 1980s. The government also raises concerns about Epstein's undisclosed foreign citizenship or residency status.

events.title: Epstein's letter submission
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein's defense team submitted a letter (ECF No. 24) asserting his Austrian passport expired 32 years ago and was never used.

events.title: Government's response letter
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office filed a response letter to Judge Berman, countering Epstein's claims about his passport and raising concerns about his foreign status.

events.title: Epstein's passport use
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein's Austrian passport contains ingress and egress stamps showing he used it to enter France, Spain, the United Kingdom, and Saudi Arabia during the 1980s.

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein possessed an Austrian passport that expired approximately 32 years prior to 2019 (around 1987).
The Austrian passport contained numerous ingress and egress stamps, showing Epstein used it to travel to France, Spain, the United Kingdom, and Saudi Arabia in the 1980s.
The government expressed concern that Epstein had not disclosed whether he is a citizen or legal permanent resident of a country other than the United States.
This document is part of the criminal case United States v. Jeffrey Epstein, 19 Cr. 490 (RMB).
